@heath please check it https://msra.org.au/ways-to-donate/gifts-in-wills-dev/ before I replace to the original page.

Lizzy

Hi Lizzy, 

Correct, for paid ads you say I want to show up for xyz keywords, (keeping in mind that Google also interprets these!). 

The organic SEO difficulty score demonstrates how many other websites are competing for that keyword string (remembering that Google decides which keywords should apply to your page). 

And yes, to rank higher, you need good quality content that talks about the subject matter. It's also a big benefit if other reputable websites talk about what you do and then link to you particular page on that topic. This positions you as an authority on the particular subject matter if other (reputable) websites are linking to you. I.e. 'go get the information straight from the horses mouth'. 

My advice, write good content that you audience is looking for and will value. Good content always wins, hands down. You write it and Google will take care of the rest.

Hi Heath,

Ok fab - in that case, let's leave the URL alone and go ahead with updating the content per the brief.

Ahhh ok, so it's just paid that you can dictate the keywords, not organic?

If that's the case, I'm less clear on what the organic SEO difficulty score shows or how you would make decisions based on it? What are the key things we can do to pages to increase their organic rankings if it's not really influenced by URL and we can't dictate the keywords? Is it just to make sure that key search terms we want to target are included in the copy (as long as they fit without looking out of place)?

Thanks

Lizzy

Hi Lizzy, 

Correct, changing the URL will only have a small impact if any. SEO is all about the sum of many small impacts though. That's how they ensure people can't abuse the algorithm and ensure a more fair playing field. 

Regarding updating the existing keywords, there is no need to update them if the content is staying the same or about the same subject matter. You don't actually give Google your keywords anymore (this stopped around 8 years ago.). They simply determine what keywords you should rank for based on your content.

Hi Heath,

Gotcha. Luckily the content is already written conversationally and definitely includes a lot of references to gifts in wills.

So in summary to that, and having done a bit more reading, am I right in thinking the URL itself doesn't have a huge impact on SEO? It is more what your keywords are for the page?…So based on that, do you think we need to create a new URL at all? Or should we just keep the existing one and update keywords for the page? (I'm not sure what the existing ones are)

Thanks

Lizzy

Hi Lizzy, 

There is no longer a 'magical ratio' for keyword saturation. In fact, if Google deems you are trying to 'game' the algorithm, they will penalise you. The rule of thumb is, if it feels right to say the keyword string, then do so... Just don't force it. Google also knows semantics, dual meanings etc., so you don't actually have to repeat that keyword string in its exact form. You could for example use things like 'when creating your will, you may want to donate some of your estate as a gift to...' Make it conversational, the moment you start writing for the search engines is when they will be onto it and the user has a poor experience on your website. I always say, Google doesn't care about the businesses, it cares about the users. The more users, the more ads they can serve, which means the more revenue they develop, it's as simple as that. So a happy user, that stays on the site and engages with good content is the ideal outcome in Googles mind. Hope that helps.

Hi Heath,

Ok great. And based on that, is there an optimum amount of times within the body copy that I need to include the phrase 'gift in a will'? Is it the more times we include that in the body copy of the page, the higher it is likely to rank in google organically?

Also in terms of Google analytics, what would be the best way to compare the previous page with the new page?

Thanks

Lizzy

Hi Lizzy, 

Yes, that's correct, in this case 'gift in a will' looks like the best option.
